subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on
the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with parapsychologist Jeffrey
Mishlove. Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey
Mishlove. Our topic today is science and post-mortem
survival. My guest, Alan Ross Hugenot, is uniquely qualified to
address this question. He has his doctorate in science, in
engineering. In addition, he is a near-death experiencer, a former board
member of the International Association for Near-Death Studies and he is a
spiritualist medium and a minister having been trained at the Morris Pratt
Institute from my home town in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, as well as the Arthur Findlay
College of Psychic Science in the United Kingdom. In addition, he is author of The
Death Experience: What It is Like When You Die, and The New Science of
Consciousness Survival: And the Metaparadigm Shift to a Conscious Universe.
Of course, we're still here in the lockdown period of Covid-19 so
virtually all of my interviews are internet-based. Now,
I'll switch over to the Skype video. Welcome Alan. It's
a pleasure to be with you. It's fun to be here. I enjoy answering questions for
anybody that asks. You have a very unusual background with an
advanced degree in engineering, a specialty in nautical engineering and a
deep understanding of physics. At the same time,
you're working as a spiritualist medium. I gather also
you're credentialed as a spiritualist minister. Yes. It's really
almost like… They used to have a TV show, I Led Three
Lives. It's like I have two different personalities,
actually. When I'm operating as a medium it actually is
like a different personality. But I'm not multiple
personality or something. But it's that way. All of
this really began for you in 1970—long before Raymond
Moody first wrote his book Life After Life about near-death experiences—when
you had what is very close to a classical near-death experience yourself.
Yes, that's true. It was difficult in the hospital
at the time because nobody would believe me.
Their standard procedure at that point if you had one of those was that you were
delusional. They wanted to send you to the nuthouse, the funny
farm, they still had funny farms then. They would send you
there until you shut up about it. They'd give you
various drugs to get you to shut up about it. I
said to the psychiatrist… He came in and he said, “You think you
died and came back and you're acting like you're Jesus or
somebody. I mean, nobody does that.” I said, “No. You're a
scientist. I respect all your degrees and all of
your advanced learning. I've been to Mexico and you
don't believe Mexico exists. Are you telling me I
haven't been to Mexico? But I've been there! You
need to step up and say, hey wait a minute, let me find
out about this. Where is this Mexico? But you're not.
You're avoiding your job.” Of course, he didn't like me so he wanted to commit
me to the nuthouse. My orthopedic surgeon, who was a much more
savvy individual, checked me out of the hospital all of a sudden one afternoon.
He comes running in—I'm wearing a hospital gown—he puts me
in a wheelchair, throws my clothes in my lap and takes me
down the freight elevator out the back
door. I get put in my mom's car and we drive
away. It was because they were trying to commit
me that day to the nuthouse. It's very disconcerting to have
them tell you you’re crazy when all you're trying
to tell them is what you saw. I did that, “I
want to tell you about this,” and they said, “You're
nuts.” You went to Niagara Falls and you’re trying to
tell somebody how wonderful it was, it was beautiful, and
they don’t believe you. It's not there, it didn’t happen.
Since you had that powerful experience, which I gather is one of the
major milestones of your life, the field of near-death studies has really
burgeoned. There's now an international association
for near-death studies and many scientific
papers have been published. You've served as a board
member of that association. Yes, that's true. I've
written a lot of things about it. We study it in great depth.
The thing that proves to us that there is consciousness survival
after physical death is the fact that all of these near-death experiencers are
having the same experience—a classical, what
Raymond Moody says are the twelve things that
happen—and they all have parts of it. They don't all have the
twelve, let's say, they'll have nine or eight or something.
They're all having the same experience when they've
never heard of it, they've never talked to each other
about it, this sneaks up on them and then they get together
and they talk, “Oh, that’s the same thing that happened
to me.” Well, then it's not a hallucination, it's not
something that's programmed into us genetically, it's
a real experience that we're having. Obviously the
consciousness is surviving outside the physical when the
physical… Pim van Lommel says it this way. The brain doesn't work after
about 30 seconds. It just stops, there's no oxygen,
there's nothing going on, it flatlines. You're having an
experience that you remember when your brain is flatlined and your
heart's not even working, there's no respiration and you're having
this thing? Yes, that's exactly it. It is the
survival of consciousness when the physical body is
basically dead by every definition we have of dead. He's referring to
cardiac arrest patients that he's studied. In your case, you were in a
motorcycle accident and you hadn't suffered a cardiac arrest.
No, I was just in a coma and in the ICU. I was in a coma for twelve hours. During
that coma, that's when I had the experience. He studies
cardiac arrest particularly because he can really say
they’re actually dead. But that study is what convinces us that what occurred
to me and what happened to the people with cardiac arrest
is a real out-of-body experience. When we talk about the
science of post-mortem survival I've heard you make an
interesting argument. It's really one of the most interesting
that I've heard and that is you refer to the law of conservation of
matter and energy. Energy is always there. E=MC2, that
combination has to go someplace. You have to have M
equal E over C squared or something. The formula has to
continue. The energy doesn't disappear, it doesn't dissipate. It can
go beyond an event horizon into a black hole but it doesn't
disappear, it doesn't stop, it's still there. Even if we
can't detect it in the black hole it's still there. When your
body dies and it just suddenly is lifeless, the life energy falls out of it.
Where does that go, that life energy, that mind? I love to go back to Max
Planck in 1900. He said we cannot get behind this fact that the matrix of
matter is mind. Matter is built on mind,
that is the matrix on which the universe exists. He said that
as early as 1900. He didn't know about near-death experiences.
He knew about the quantum and he was working on these things.
But mind is what the whole universe is made up of. You
can't get beyond that. We back away from materializing or
apprehending the physical and we back away into
another part of our same universe, I'd like
to call it dark energy otherwise, and we step back into that and we drop the
physical like taking off my jacket, if I was to take a
jacket off and just leave it behind. That's what your
physical is, it's a jacket you just throw away, you don't need
it anymore because you're now outside of what… I like what
Betty White says—Stewart White's wife who was a medium and then she worked from
the other side back to here. The Unobstructed Universe
is the book to read—she talks about there's two
universes. There's the one you guys are stuck in over here in the physical and
then there's all the rest of it out here. She says, “I'm out in the rest of it and
I'm not obstructed by the physical like you are.” In other
words, she can go through a wall. We can't go through a
wall. We'd bang up against it and we can't get past it. She goes right in
through it and it doesn't bother her because it's not within her
perceptive level at her vibration, or how you want to say it,
her frequency. Her frequency is higher than that or
lower than that or something. It sounds like with your
background in engineering and physics and your work as a spiritualist medium
that you think that perhaps we'll arrive at a point where we'll have some sort of
technology that will enable us to communicate
with people on the other side. That is my hope.
Gary Schwartz has been doing some work at the University of Arizona
on the cell phone, soul phone he calls it. He's able to get
indications from what he calls hypothetical people on the other side. He
gets back signals from them, he's working on signal transfer. He's got some
pretty good stuff. Hopefully, we'll be able to turn that someday.
This has been the goal since Edison, he had this goal also.
He wanted to do this and so did Tesla. They were
all trying to do this. We haven't brought something
that's sold the rest of science on it yet. However, since we have discovered
dark holes and dark energy science is now realizing there's
all this stuff they don't know, 96% of the universe they don't know. These things
are suddenly back in the realm of possibility, so
we're working on them. Let's talk about your work as a
spiritualist medium. You went to get formal training, this was sometime
after your own near-death experience, you studied at various spiritualist
schools to become accredited as a medium. I guess that you must have had some
natural talent to begin with. I think everyone has this talent. It's the sixth
sense that we sort of ignore. When we come as children
we actually have much more of it. We sort of put
it in the back and forget about it and start using our five senses.
Children have imaginary friends and things like that. I don't know that
they're so imaginary, I think they're just seeing on the other side. Anyway,
I think we all have this talent and we can use it if we develop it. What I
did when I began to approach retirement from the active
engineering field, I decided in 2006 that I would study mediumship
because I knew that the people who were on the
other side, I knew we could go out of body.
I knew that we've been having lots and lots of people
tell us they've been getting messages and information from
these other people that were over there. So I decided, okay, so they are there
and I know they're there and I've been over there so why
can't I talk to them? I went into becoming a medium with
belief that I can do this. There's no reason I can't. I
just have to learn how. Most people who do it they say,
well, I'm gifted. No, they’re no more gifted than the next
guy. They have just sharpened it like a concert pianist
sharpens his ability by practice. By that practice you learn. I
found out that the Morris Pratt Institute offered a
correspondence course. It took about four years then. We
had to read 40-50 books and then report on them and
know all about the whole background of spiritualism.
I signed up for that course and I studied it and I finished it. The mediums
that I worked with, people like Suzanne Giesemann,
they said, you need to go to Arthur Findlay College,
which is in Essex England, in Stansted. I went there. I've been there
five times and I stay a week or two weeks every time I go there. I've taken advanced
classes and this is kind of like graduate school. You
go nine hours a day and they feed you there, they house
you there. It’s very intensive. You go for seven days for nine hours a day.
You're done with that session and then you take another session. There I
learned from some very learned
mediums who have 30-40 years in the business
and they really know what they're doing.
In one class I was bringing through the grandfather of another girl in the
class, there were about 14 of us in this advanced class.
I was bringing through her grandfathering and I said, “His
name's Frederic and I see him wearing a three-piece suit
and he's in Glasgow and he's working in a shipyard.”
Of course, being a naval architect I'm thinking, “Oh, you're
making that up, Alan.” But I didn't say it, I just thought
it in my head. The instructor, who's reading my thoughts psychically,
she's reading the spirits' thoughts also. She
said, “Alan, he's not going to show up for
the nurse over there in the back of the room. You're a
naval architect. He's going to come to you if you're on the
platform. He's coming to you now because you're a naval
architect and you worked in a shipyard because you would
understand him.” She said all that to me and I never said
anything about my doubts, she read my mind. She said, “Now
tell me more about him.” “OK, he works in the
administrative department, he doesn't actually work out
with the ships themselves.” She says, “What kind of a house does he
live in?” I started describing the house that she's
given to me. She says, “What street?” And I said,
“Oak.” I mean, Oak Street, good grief, this is the stuff
that's coming through and she's teaching me how to reach
out and get that information which is just beyond my
imagination. It's hard to tell it from imagination. I'm reaching out and
finding that information that he's handing me, not questioning it, just
taking it. I brought through a lot of information. She's
the type of lady that says, “So, is there a truck parked
there? What's the license?” That's the kind of thing she'd do. I
learned how to go beyond my ego and
surrender to what's coming in. Now, I'm tearing up because I'm moving
in that direction. Like I say, it's two different
personalities and I get emotional and very intense. When I'm
talking to you I'm trying to use what I will call the
professor, and the other one is the medium. The medium is a
jellyfish, a pushover, it’s so emphatic that I can't
quite control everything. It takes over like that.
That's how you really get the good information.
It'll show you pictures, it'll show you all kinds of stuff. It's all in your
imagination, it's happening in a certain little corner back here—I
can't remember all the parts of the lobes—but anyway,
it's happening in a certain place where your mind, your
brain, changes visual things into words. That happens in Broca's fissure,
or something like that, it's got a name. That's where
you do that. You change your thoughts, your visions, your
symbols into words that you can say audibly. It sounds like what you're
doing is at the conscious level. You're not going into a deep trance and losing
consciousness. No, I don't do that. I'm doing it totally by… I feel it all. I
t's a sensory thing. I feel a name. Now, how do you feel a name?
People say, “That smell has a color.” Yes, it does.
It's at the same vibratory level. I feel names.
It's very hard to describe. People think they're gonna tell you their
name, say it in your ear. No, I feel their name. I feel how they look.
I feel the vision that I have of them and it's not auditory.
It's totally feeling, totally sensory
from right here. I should probably just say
for the benefit of our viewers we've switched
rooms in order to get a better technical quality in our signal. I'll
just repeat where we were before. You're describing how the
information seems to come to your chest and how emotional it is for
you when you do this mediumship work. I'm
under the impression that many of the messages are all about love. People
on the other side want to communicate how much love
they feel for the people who are still over here. That's
absolutely true, Jeffrey. It comes into this area because of the
chakras that are involved. It's a life energy. If you
consider that there are two kinds of energy. There's
electromechanical energy and then there's life energy. Life
energy moves from the heart chakra, it doesn't move from the
brain. The brain hardly puts out anything at all but this
area puts out all kinds of stuff and it takes it in
and it's coming in here. Life has to do with love.
Love and life are almost inseparable. They're bringing
their love back for the people who are still
living here and they're trying to share
that. They use the life energy. It's a form of energy we haven't yet
measured. It's in the dark energy somewhere. We will measure it. It
may be a monopole in this physical 3D reality that we have, but
it's really a bi-pole system and the other half of it is on
the other side. So we don't detect it because we only get
half of it. We detect something when we have
both parts, the positive and negative. We only
got the positive or we only got the negative. We’ve only got
a piece of it. We don't get the whole thing so it's a monopole
instead of a bi-pole. When we learn how to detect the whole thing then we’ll
suddenly say, “Oh look at all this energy going around between people.” You're
walking in a room, you feel a guy on the other side. He's in a bad mood, I
can feel it. That's the life energy that's moving. That's how
they communicate with us, through that energy. When
you love somebody you get a whole lot more of that.
You totally can read them from across the room. You know exactly
what's going on with them and it's all felt, it isn't said, it isn't
visual, it's felt. That's how they communicate with us. What's
happening is, when I'm being a medium I'm communicating to the other side. The
person who is wanting to talk to them is here but
they're not feeling it but I'm feeling it for them.
It’s like they're holding my hand while I'm talking to the
other side. I work through Helen. She's on that side, she’s been
there for over a quarter of a century and she talks to me because she
knows me really well and she can make me feel exactly what I'm supposed to say
to this person. I'm supposed to say, “I see a skier over there.
He liked to ski, did he?” She's showing me something that reminds
me of skiing so I'll say that. I loved it when I was doing it for a girl
named Angela one time and I had her fiance who had died. Helen gave
me basketballs. I said, “Oh, he likes basketball?”
She said, “He doesn't even like sports.” Oh, okay.
I couldn't figure that out. After the session was over I was talking to
Helen at three o'clock in the morning and said, “Helen, what
was that about?” She gave me this thought. She said, “His
name was Jag. The one basketball player that you
have known personally at that time,” I know another
one, “but the only professional basketball player you
know is Jack Sigma of the Seattle Sonics. You knew him
so I gave you basketball so you’d think of Jack and
then you'd say his name.” I went back to Angela a week
later and said, “Angela, was his name Jack?” She said, “No, it was Jacques.” So,
Helen and I learn over time what symbols will
make me do what. She can touch me and make me say things so I get the correct signal,
the correct vision, and the correct symbol to say the thing that the sitter,
the person that is trying to communicate to the other side, will know so I can
bring through the name like that. If I could have said to
Angela, “His name is Jack.” “No, it’s Jaques, but that’s him!”
I want that kind of information to come through so I can put tears in the
eyes of this person so they realize, “Wow, you really are connecting with Jack
or Jacques.” So that's how it's done. It's a deeply emotional thing.
Helen is your spirit guide. Yes, she's a spirit guide. I've never met her in
this life. She is my wife's mother and I met
her daughter five years after she died and
then I married her daughter. When I started doing
mediumship, she shows up. Every time I go to a medium,
here's Helen. I remember this one Danish girl was giving me
a reading at Arthur Findlay College and she said, “Oh, that
woman over your left shoulder there. Is her name Helen?” She'll show up. One time I'm
working with another medium who knew about Helen. He says,
“Oh Alan, I've got this woman but it's not Helen. Her name
is Dorothy.” Well, that's her middle name. She sneaks up and she pulls this
stuff off and there she is. People will say, “Oh, he's reading
your mind,” and all that. No, she's really
there. She shows up every time I go to a medium.
In the early times I would get information I didn't
know about my mother-in-law that I never met. I’d
have to go to my wife and find out, oh yeah that's true, she did that. She'd be
telling me something that wasn't in my mind, that the medium
couldn't be reading for me, and then I’d go verify the fact
later. She works with me. She's the
medium, I'm the medium, and we're sitting next to each
other. Then there's the departed soul sitting there and then
there's the sitter, the one who wants to talk to the
departed soul. There's four of us in a row. If we whisper
down the lane, if we played that little game, it will
come out a little bit garbled on the end, wouldn't it?
Some people say, “Well, you're wrong.” One time I'm doing
mediumship and I say to the woman, “I have your mother
here,” and I give her the name. I'm talking about her mother by name. I
said, “She loved cooking.” The lady was a little distracted
by her child playing or something, she said, “No, she
didn't. She hated cooking. She was in service in a
large mansion and she hated cooking. That's what she did
for her whole life.” What she had told me, what the
spirit had brought through, was that she was a cook. I
colored it by saying she loved cooking. I put that she loved it in there.
That's the garble that happens. Then the lady decides
I'm totally wrong because I said the word, “loved
cooking.” She was a cook for her whole life. I had a fact here
that was real and yet the lady discounted the fact, said
you're no good. I've already given her the name, she's a
cook. “You're no good, you don't know what you’re doing.” She didn't
believe in the connection anymore and there it goes. That's
the hardest part of mediumship, to work with the person
here and their skepticism. I may get half of
the things right, then I'm batting 500. Most
people don't bat above 250, they get a quarter
of it right, the baseball players. Sometimes I'm
at 85 percent right and there's only 15 percent that's garble that's
in there. But the garble, if people will jump on and say, “Not
true, it's no good.” That's very disappointing. I'm under the
impression from people I know who have become spiritualists that probably the
most convincing aspect for them isn't the information, it's the emotional
connection. These people really believe that they are working through
unresolved emotions, typically that they have with their deceased parents. I truly
believe there is no retribution, there is only remorse.
Suppose you were an SS officer in a Nazi death camp.
What remorse you must have, and how long does it take to
work through all of that? When we first get over there, what
the Catholics identified as purgatory, doesn't exist in that sense. But it does
exist in the fact that we have to work through that.
The near-death experience has the life review. The
life review is just a foretaste of what goes on through
quite a little while after we get over there working through
the remorse about this life so that we can move on from
this life. We're still kind of oriented to this life and
tied to this physical life that we had while
we worked through that remorse. We look at
everything we ever did. In a near-death experience,
in the life review, you look at everything from the
other person's side of the table, instead of your side. How did they feel when
you said that? Why did you say that? You have to work all
of that out. I love what Banks says… Frances Banks and
Helen Greaves wrote a book in 1967 called The Testimony of Light.
Frances Banks is the deceased who was writing back from the other side and
describing… She says, you get two blueprints: how
it should have been and how you did it. You look at
those two blueprints and she says it's sometimes just
devastating to look at it. She said many people, when they
first get to the other side, can't hardly look at
it. It’s just so painful they’d do anything else,
they just wait. So it takes them a long time to work
through the remorse because they have to look at everything.
The other one that Frances Banks brought up, she had an SS officer she
was talking about. She said with the SS officer—this is 1967
and it had been more than 20 years—he had been
just over in the shadows there. With him was the
Jewish lady that hated him because he killed her husband
and children. But her hatred kept her with him. She needed
to release that hatred in order to move forward. Her husband
and children were already over there and she's been 22
years with this SS officer, hating him, viscerally
hating him. She's missing out on spending the—time is different over there—
but spending the time with her husband and her children
which is what she was mad at him for. But she has to go over
why she's mad at him in order to move on. That remorse
thing is very difficult. Some people spend 50 years
over there. Other people get right through it because they say, okay, I've
got to improve, we're evolving. That's what it's
like. If you want to know what it's like on the
other side do read the book, The Testimony of Light by
Helen Greaves, 1967. I'm under the impression that time
and space are very different over there and that also,
maybe more important than time and space completely,
is this dimension of consciousness. I think you referred to it as a vibration.
It's a frequency. Our understanding of consciousness is now
moving forward on the cutting edge of parapsychology, it's moving forward quite
rapidly. We're making inroads. We're beginning
to understand it. That part of the universe is
entirely conscious. The consciousness… If you think about
what Max Planck said, that mind is the matrix of matter.
Matter can't exist except as apprehended consciousness. We bring it in space and
time and it manifests for us and we see it there. If you think about the universe as
appearing for you, from the dark energy it appears for you, it materializes in front
of you the way you wish to see it. Some of that wish is corporate,
we do it as a whole group of all of us at once thinking
about how we want to see it. It materializes out of the
dark energy. It annihilates and it comes back.
This is doing it 23 septillion times a second.
It's really vibrating. You think, well, I'm sitting on the chair, the chair
didn't disappear. No, it did, it disappeared and came
back again. It’s rematerializing all the time for
you, 23 septillion times a second. People say, how fast is that?
It's hard to explain.
Put a bunch of zeroes….
You have to realize,
the universe appears around you and you can influence that. Consciousness is
what the universe is made out of.
Think about the string in string theory.
If you can picture a string that’s vibrating but there's no string there,
just the vibration.
That’s a consciousness, that's a thought, that
has no physical reality.
That's what the whole universe is built on:
consciousness.
It’s a thought. Thoughts are things.
Once you get all this stuff, all this
esoteric metaphysical descriptions and
language, it makes more sense.
It all adds up and fits together.
It sort of reminds me of
the Cheshire cat in Lewis Carroll’s Alice in Wonderland,
only the smile is left.
The cat disappears and just smiles.
That's a good way to describe it.
Once you get all this...
I wish we could bring it to people,
the peace which passes all human understanding, that's what comes,
this super peace.
The Cheshire cat just sits there.
The fool on the hill,
he is so happy, he is so peaceful
looking down at everybody.
That’s what it is. People say, oh, you’re such a fool. Yes, that’s right. I am
the fool on the hill and it's a great place to be. Then I shift back
to the professor, from the medium to the professor, and I do
want to put this into a context people can understand. What
I would recommend that many people do, and it may be ignored
these days because it's a little difficult to work through,
is The Betty Book and The Unobstructed
Universe and the other books by Stewart White
that go with it. They're in a series and if you pull out the
series they're just a great set of books. The Unobstructed
Universe explains so much. You sometimes have to digress and go
study, what did that mean, with some of the scientific
terms. Once you get them, Stewart and Betty are
talking all the time and they put in these scientific
terms and you have to know what they are. If you can bear
with yourself and go get the dictionary and look that up and figure
out what was that term, what did that mean? You can Google it, you can
work at it. It’s a wonderful book, The Unobstructed Universe. It's a book that
has been recommended to me for many decades, as a matter of fact. You wrote
about your own near-death experience and you described it in very different terms.
As I recall, you made the point of saying that here in
the physical world we think of objects as being outside of
ourselves and we study them, as you just described,
look up the dictionary definition. But on the
inner planes you don't study objects or individuals, you become them, you
learn of them from the inside. When you encountered this being of light it
wasn't so much you encountering the being as you becoming that being. It was
me returning to myself. I had known the being of light for eons. I
must have been around too, and I've been around for eons, and here I am just
bumping into myself. “Hi, there.” “Oh, it's you.” You see an old
friend that you haven't seen in a hundred years, it’s like,
“Oh my, it's you. Hi.” It was like that. No introduction.
Everybody says, “Who was it that you saw? Was it a
Christian? Was it Jesus? Who was that? Was it Buddha?”
No, it was me and I'm back to myself. I'm home, home like you could never
understand. We all want to go home, to the real place where we came from. That's it.
I was there. I was home again. Then I got this message from the being of light.
You get it by ESP, you don't get it by hearing it or anything.
The message came, “You have to go back.” I said, “No, I don't want
to go back. I don't want to go back at all. I like it here. Let me
stay right here. I'm home.” The being said… I'll say he said but it all came
as a feeling, “You're not done. You're not done with what you were put there to
do. You have a destiny. You must go back and fulfill it.” So I'm here and that's
what I'm doing. The way that it works, it's always
becoming, it's always about being but we have a feeling that we want to become
even more than just be. Just be, I’m bored. I'm just being here. I'm bored. I
want to become. We want to grow, we want to go
further. We want to discover more. That process of
going down the path is what life is. Life is the journey on the path. It is not
arriving. I sail. I’m a sailor. When we're out in the boat and
there's a little kid on the boat who says, “When are we gonna get there?”
“We're there. We're sailing now.” “No. When are we gonna get there? We're
crossing this water. When are we gonna get there? There!” It is being there, it is
the becoming. We become all the time moving on that journey. The guides on the other
side show me each step, one step at a time. I have to look at the step.
The hard part is, there's the step, I have to take it. It's
in front of me, I don't know what's coming but I'm
gonna take that step. In each step, when you get to look
back in hindsight, you can see
what happened in hindsight, why it was that you took the step, you couldn't
see it going in but you get to look back and see it. Then the
next step comes, and again they've handed me another step.
I have to take that step. If I try to figure it out I'll be wrong. I'll see
this as an evil thing when it's a good thing. I'll be
wrong if I try to figure out, if I take that step what's
gonna happen? We always try to second-guess ourselves.
“I'm gonna figure that out before I make that move.”
No, the move is there, the door is open, the window is open,
take it, jump out the window, go. You will be absolutely
amazed by what happens when you take the step. If you don't take it you're
stuck, you’re stuck in a box, you can't get over there,
you're in a prison. But if you take the step amazing
things happen, things you could not have foreseen. Just going
down that street, here comes somebody you needed to meet
that you never ever would've met. I was watching
a documentary on Westinghouse. When he went to
Pittsburgh, the first days there he meets the guy
that he spends the rest of his life working with,
one of his investors. He's just walking up the street and
he asks directions from the guy. How did the guy get on the
street? This super relationship comes
out of this, “Hey, do you know how to get to the…” There's the guy.
When you look at life and understand the synergism that happens, that man was
walking down the street so Westinghouse could meet him.
It’s just the way it was. There was Westinghouse, he got
himself to Pittsburgh, he got on that street and he asked
the question. And there it was. Those things happen when
you take the step. If you don't take the step you won't
be on that street and you won’t see the guy. You've
closed yourself off in this little box. You have to take the step. Of course,
it's a different step for each person. Yes, it is. We each have our own destiny
which is based a lot on who we are and how we're put together,
our state of it and where we're evolved to at the moment. People like
to say we signed a contract. No, I like to say there were two blueprints. There
was the one that could have been and the one that we did. It's all up to us
with free will. It's not predestined with a contract that
I have to do it. That's my destiny if I choose to do it,
if I will to do it. The choice is always a free choice. We have
free will. We're not driven. We don't have to rob the bank. We wanted to rob
the bank. When somebody says, “Oh, I couldn't
help it. I robbed the bank because of the way my
father treated me.” No. We chose, we did, we made the move. We can't blame someone
else or something else. It's us that chooses. We have free will. We're not
predestined. Determination, that the world is determinate, is
something I can disprove and I do in my book. I take the first
principles of physics and I take each one of them out
and show how they’re presumptions and assumptions.
We can no longer uphold them with
our quantum physics. They don't fit. If we're going to
believe in quantum physics and relativity we cannot believe
in those things. They're not real. It was a hard one for
Einstein. He worked on this all the time. He
wanted to be a materialist and he knew he'd lost it
and he couldn't go back there and he struggled with it. David Bohm and
he spent a lot of time trying to work it all
out. For physicists, you need to read all
of David Bohm’s books, I’m sorry. You just need to. You need to
understand the implicate order and the explicate order. You need
to understand that there's the potential of the implicate
order and this is the explicate order which we precipitate
through the collapse of the wave function. We precipitate it, we create the world
that's around us, and we do it from the potential. The
whole universe is standing there as potential for each of
us to develop that potential. It will just materialize and
manifest in front of us. I spend a lot of time trying to
figure out how to say this to people in ways that it's gonna make
sense to them, that they are going to understand. People come up
to me and they say, “I'd love to read your book,
Alan, but could you put it into three or four
sentences so I can just get it?” I say, “It's not like that. What you're saying is,
I'm too damn lazy to do my own homework. I don't want
to learn. I don't want anything to change because I
might have to learn a new software program in order to do the thing. I don't
want to take the time to learn. I'm too busy.” If you want the feeling and the
peace that passes all human understanding and the
confidence about life, that this is wonderful,
you're going to have to do the homework. The homework takes
some time. I can't put it in three sentences. I might be
able to put it in three volumes about three inches
thick and put it all in there, but if you will get
on the path and take each step as its put in front of you
and do the homework, do the reading, do the looking up of
the definitions to get it, and stop being lazy about it saying, “I'm gonna spend
two minutes on this then I got to go somewhere.” No, if
you're gonna go on this path you have to dedicate to the path.
You have to make it part of you and then it'll work, then you'll get it and you'll
understand it. Everybody wants to do everything
so fast, just like that, one thing just like that.
They can’t. It won't. Let me ask you a tough question.
Pretty much all the mystics, and I know you've kind of been
hinting at it yourself, will tell us that everything is
one, it's all one, there's one consciousness and that's the universe.
That being the case, why are we encapsulated in our own individual
bodies? Why does it seem as if we're all separate individuals
when we're really all one? That's a great question.
We've been asking that one for several thousand years. Why was this
done? The best way I can try to explain that is,
let's imagine that you’re god. It's not a being like us.
He experiences things. He/she experiences things, feels things. God is sitting there
one day and has a thought. I would like to know what it would be like to be the
victim who was murdered. How does that feel? I would also like to know,
how does it feel to be the guy doing the murdering? How does
that feel? In order to do that I have to have a murderer and
a murderee. This brilliant consciousness, God,
thought of all these billions of people doing all of these
billions of things so he could feel all of that and see how
all of that was. That makes sense to me. I want to have
it all. I want to have it all. He/she wants to have it all
and does this, creates the whole
universe. Alan Hugenot, this has been a delightful conversation. We've covered a
lot of ground here. Any question you have to finish this off… What you've been
saying reminds me of, I think it was Einstein actually,
who said the most important question we can ask is, is the
universe friendly? I've definitely got the impression from you that the
answer is yes. It's yes, if you see it that way. It's all about your perception.
How do you see the universe? What does your culture give
you that causes you to fear or love? If you see the universe
as a wonderful loving place then that's what
it is. If you see it as a terrible place,
then that's what it is. It's up to you with your free will to choose that it's a

in closing, I want to say this to everyone, if you fear death start

says, “Oh you, you can't wait.” That's right.
I was home and I want to go home again.
That's how I felt when I was there. I was home. I did
not want to come back here. When it finally comes,
my ultimate you gotta go, I'm happy, I'm excited and I can't wait to get there.
That's a much better way to look at death than to say, “Oh my god,

I've learned patience. I'm willing to live out my destiny but I
